title: keir starmer posh remainer leader
story: It was this “Posh Trot” Remainer who drove a bulldozer through Labour’s so-called Red Wall and cleared the path for Boris Johnson’s invasion of its northern heartlands.It was Starmer’s campaign for a chaotic second referendum that persuaded millions of working-class supporters to vote Tory for the first time and condemn Labour to the political wilderness.Not surprisingly, Starmer’s critics now wonder why this proven loser is in pole position to run their party.Some point the finger at Gordon Brown quietly rallying supporters to the cause.The ex-PM and his protegé have been close since Starmer’s controversial reign as Director of Public Prosecutions from  to .Starmer, despite his reputation for defending human rights, is not above sly ploys.There is nothing wrong with being wealthy — except among the Momentum voters he needs to seize Labour’s crown. Perhaps this explains why his Wikipedia entry has just been doctored to delete his status as a “millionaire”. Not me, guv, protests Starmer.He is also weirdly reluctant to declare where he stands on the political spectrum. Is he a Corbynite or a Blairite or a bit of both  “I don’t have the names of former leaders tattooed on my head,” snfs the man named at birth after the first leader of the Labour Party.This knight of the realm, who played violin at fee-paying Reigate Grammar School alongside Fatboy Slim, claims a humble background as the son of a toolmaker.“I know what it’s like,” he insists, asraised in a cardboard box.Well, I went to the same school when it was a “bog-standard” state grammar. My father was a journeyman upholsterer. It didn’t give me any special insights.Starmer boasts in his new campaign video about picket-line stints alongside down- trodden Wapping printworkers — against my boss, Rupert Murdoch, a hate figure on the Left.This chameleon politician was dubbed a “Sir” on the recommendation of Gordon Brown, a title he discourteously declines to use because it invites contempt among those with a vote.His citation was for “services to law and criminal justice”, after a five-year term as DPP.At about the same time he was parachuted into Parliament as MP for rock-solid Labour Holborn and St Pancras, in London.It is here that self-respecting Labour voters should pause and reflect.Many believe these political plums were reward for the longest, costliest and perhaps most spiteful criminal persecution in history — ordered by Sir Keir Starmer.His new leadership video slyly refers to this time, apparently to boost his scourge-of-capitalism image among the “comrades” — even though politics should play no part in a DPP’s decision-making. In a travesty of justice, he rammed two dozen innocent journalists through Old Bailey trials on trumped-up conspiracy charges — a medieval catch-all which even the Crown Prosecution Service admitted was “an extremely dficult and rarely visited area of the law”.The prosecuting counsel was given a flea in his ear for “chopping and changing”, the charges against the journalists.The trials ended with acquittals all round, an admission that “no crime may have been committed” and this rebuke from the Lord Chief Justice:“What concerns me is the freedom of the Press and the desire of officials to contain information.“We must ensure the Press is protected — we can’t use criminal sanctions to undermine their position.”The defendants were all journalists on The Sun or the News of the World — then seen by the Left as fair game.The trials followed The Sun’s decision to switch its support from Gordon Brown’s floundering regime to David Cameron’s Tories.Some believe the two were linked — but surely that’s just a conspiracy theory.What is absolutely clear to those who care about the issue is Starmer’s readiness to use his power to curb Press freedom.As citizens of totalitarian regimes rapidly learn to their cost, without a free Press there is no such thing as free speech.IT’S win-win for the Sussexes and losses all round for the House of Windsor.Meghan’s first kiss-and-tell will be a bestseller, with all the gossip on Randy Andy and those secret royal scandals.Harry’s right-on charities will be milked for millions.Once our revered Queen has departed, the monarchy will dwindle to a sideshow on the US celebrity circuit.Charles is too old to compete and William is too dull, despite Kate’s best efforts.Hero Harry will emerge as victor in this grotesque civil war. I predict he will live to regret it. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: queen must be firm harry meghan
story: So we hope that Meghan and Harry can come to a suitable arrangement with the rest of the royals.But what’s clear is the couple must not receive a penny from the state.British taxpayers fund the Royal Family to strengthen our nation’s soft power, and to support vital charities.If Meghan and Harry can’t be bothered with the legwork, then it goes without saying they must give up the whopping perks which come with it.As for security, claims that to stay safe the pair need cash from daddy just won’t wash. The Duke and Duchess of Sussex are rich beyond the wildest dreams of almost everyone in the UK.They are more than capable of paying for a few bodyguards. Andthey find themselves struggling, they could always cut down on the private jets.The Queen, Charles and Wills must be firm: the Sussexes have made their bed. Now they’ve got to lie in it.A CIVILISED nation treats its veterans with respect.Which is why we were delighted when Boris Johnson won the election on a manesto promising to end witch hunt prosecutions against ageing former soldiers who served in Northern Ireland.But to get Stormont up and running, the Prime Minister has brokered a deal with Sinn Fein which risks opening up new probes into thousands of Troubles veterans. This would be morally indefensible and politically mad.Yes, a working government in Northern Ireland would be a good thing. But the safety and wellbeing of our elderly veterans is too big a price tag.And given Boris won the election by being a proud patriot, it makes political sense for him to stand by the armed forces through thick and thin.If the PM is to hold the hard-earned trust of new Conservative voters, he must never give way to those who would put our old soldiers in the dock.IT would be fair to assume that anyone injecting plastic into someone’s face should have some qualications to do so.But a strange loophole in the law means that though Botox is classied as a medicine in Britain, dermal fillers aren’t covered by any regulation.A staggering  per cent of facial fillers are performed by people with no medical training, often in unsanitary conditions — with devastating results.Which is why The Sun’s Fabulous brand is launching the Had Our Fill campaign, urging for a crackdown on unregulated cosmetic fillers, and raising awareness to help women make safer, more informed choices.We’ve had our fill of dodgy fillers. title: meghan markle racism press bigotry
story: By “they” I mean the liberal-Left commentariat, the people who hate Brexit, hate ordinary people and have, for some reason, grown to love our departing royals, Prince Harry and Meghan.This past  hours they have closed ranks around the couple, who have announced they plan to keep their royal titlesbut leave behind their royal duties — like some woke version of the Queen’s Guard.They have chastised anyone outraged by the staggering entitlement shown by the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, who have essentially said they want the status but none of the responsibilities of monarchy.They insist the poor couple have been driven out by racism.British author Afua Hirsch, writing in the New York Times, decries the “racist treatment of Meghan” in the Press.She says it is hardly a surprise Meghan has walked away from a nation with a Prime Minister “whose track record includes overtly racist statements” and a “Brexit project linked to native nationalism”.Boris Johnson has no such track record and the only people linking Brexit to native nationalism are elitist, upper-crust Remainers like Hirsch.But no matter. Why let reality spoil the narrative These claims made about the “racist” treatment of Meghan at the hands of the British Press are incredibly thin.The same non-examples are recycled over and over again. You have probably seen them quoteda thousand times.There is that Mail Online piece from , when Harry and Meghan were first dating, that said she was “ straight outta Compton”.At the time, Meghan’s mother Doria Ragland lived in nearby Crenshaw, LA.Hirsch says this was an attempt to link Meghan with “racialised forms of crime”, meaning gangs.That is one hell of a reach. The piece was clearly just playing on the dference in Harry and Meghan’s social backgrounds.If Harry had been dating a white, working-class woman from Manchester’s Moss Side, I dare say the Mail would have done something similarly silly.Another favourite is that weird throwaway line Boris Johnson’s sister Rachel wrote, in a laudatory piece on Meghan, about the mixed-race American actress bringing some “rich and exotic DNA” to the pale Windsor bloodline. That is more cringey than racist.Several pieces have cited a single phrase in a Sarah Vine column for the Mail — she said she had a “niggling worry” about the royal couple’s engagement photo — as a bigoted dog whistle. That is, quite frankly, mental.Such is the lack of actual examples of the Press being racist about Meghan.The only leg this argument has left to stand on is that the sheer volume of criticism sent Meghan’s way was disproportionate.Racism is the only explanation for it. It’s an argument based purely on unveriable speculation and imputing motives. title: meghan markle not pitchforked off uk
story: It follows the fortunes, or rather, misfortunes, of Americans who fall in love with foreigners and have just over three months to get married or send them home.A massive leap of faith, it’s usually a matter of days — sometimes hours — before the clash of cultures, personalities, values and expectations make this the television gt that keeps on giving.Perhaps Meghan and Harry should sign up for season eight. For how much did they really know about each other before walking down the aisle Prince William apparently advised his more impetuous brother to wait so he could really get to know his American bride first, but Harry took umbrage and didn’t listen.Perhapshe had, he might have worked out in advance that an independent spirit joining such a restrictive institution wasn’t going to end well.Instead, they leapt before they looked and, with the “-month bride” having packed her bags already, have saddled the -year-old Queen with yet another constitutional crisis.Back in , I wrote a piece defending Meghan after she was criticised by old school friend Ninaki Priddy for being “calculated in the way she handled people and relationships” and a “curator of a beautul le”.But following the lavish baby shower, the jet-setting with A-listers and the swt jettisoning of inconveniently outspoken family members, the latter sentiment now rings true.And, of course, becoming a member of the most famous royal family in the world was the cherry on the top of that beautul le.But Meghan soon discovered it was nothing like the membership of her beloved Soho House.The rooms are draughty, the decor chintzy and, instead of reading the morning papers in your cashmere loungewear, you have to rise early, put on a frock and make your way to some rain-lashed outpost to open the new wing of a community centre where “live your best le” sentiments, however well-meaning, aren’t required.Here’s what is required as a member of the British Royal Family: Turn up on time, shake hands, smile, say little more than “have you come far ” Repeat.Not because the royals don’t have anything to say. They do, and air their views in private.But in public, their job is to shine a light on whatever project they’re visiting, not themselves. To show — via action, not virtue-signalling statements — a strong sense of duty.And inthey get to keep their ious mansions, hundreds of staff, personal bodyguards etc without any whf of civil unrest.That’s the deal.But those still in Meghan’s social circle glowingly describe her as organised, focused, and opinionated — very much an independent woman used to having her voice heard.As Prince Harry told courtiers just before their wedding: “What Meghan wants, Meghan gets.”An admirable quality when it comes to breaking through the glass ceiling of corporate le or securing the best table in the best restaurant, perhaps.But the monarchy is an institution steeped in hundreds of years of tradition, and Meghan — who claimed she “didn’t know much” about Harry when they first met — clearly thought she’d mould it to her way of thinking . . . then rapidly discovered that it ain’t for turning.Not that The Queen didn’t try very hard to accommodate the wants and needs of the newly anointed Duke and Duchess of Sussex.Contrary to royal tradition, they were permitted to keep the christening of baby Archie as a private affair and, despite there being a perfectly nice home at Kensington Palace they could have used, a publicly funded, £.million renovation of Frogmore Cottage was authorised.A “cottage” I might add, that used to be five homes but has now been knocked in to one because they managed to dodge the usual ban that prevents such moves because of the UK’s housing crisis.Shortly after, Prince Charles launched his blueprint to try to solve the dilemma faced by millions of young people struggling to find a home of their own. Oh the irony. And after all that, they now want to use it part-time as they flit back and forth across the Atlantic.Meghan is feeling disillusioned and homesick. We get it, and sympathise.But let’s not pretend, as some claim, that she’s been practically pitchforked off this island by racist bigots.This is not a racist country and, besides, the British public initially greeted her engagement and later marriage to Harry with unbridled joy.We love Harry. He’s a thoroughly decent person and deserves particular praise for the work he’s done with the Armed Forces, both while serving and afterwards.No, the disconnect has come from the fact that Meghan is still a Hollywood celebrity at heart and, consequently, never truly settled in her often boring and restrictive new role.She misses the relative freedom of her old le, not to mention her family and friends.Again, we get it. But was it really necessary to flee these shores asescaping for her le Clearly besotted with her, Harry faces the stark decision of giving her what she wants or losing her for ever. Or perhaps he’s genuinely sick of royal le and wants out too.If so, let’s wave goodbye and wish them luck.But. The have-cake-and-eat-it plan to stop being a “senior royal” and just dip in and out of duties that suit them simply isn’t going to work.SussexRoyal — which Harry and Meghan have registered as an official trademark for everything from “emotional support services” to clothing and magazines — is a title and privilege that comes with duties and conditions attached, not a brand, be it charitable or otherwise.The future of the monarchy depends on the goodwill, support and interest level of the public, and a recent survey showed that, while the majority have no issue with their decision to go, they were strongly against any continued taxpayer funding of their lavish lestyle.So— as early indicators go — The Queen allows Harry and Meghan to call the shots while keeping their royal titles, their taxpayer-funded security and an allowance from the Duchy of Cornwall, then one suspects this will be discussed by students for centuries to come as the turning point at which the British monarchy began its steady decline to irrelevance and, ultimately, abolition.MOVIE mega-star Will Smith popped in to the retirement party of a woman he last met  years ago.Anita Scipio was the receptionist at a US radio station when Will arrived for one of his first interviews as a young actor and he’s never forgotten how nice she was to him.“My favorite moments on the road are the ones where I can connect with people like @anitascipio,” -year-old Will told his Instagram followers before he walked in to the station to give her a hug.In the days before social media, someone who worked at his record company Sony told me that whenever he was in town, Will would tour the building, from post room to boardroom, giving time to everyone.He’s that rare creature, a star on screen and off.Some of today’s petulant slebs should watch and learn.FORMER psychiatric nurse Susan Evans is launching a landmark legal case to challenge consent issues around the provision of puberty blockers and cross-sex hormones for under-s.She argues that children should be protected from “experimental” and “invasive medical treatment”, not least because “some children are referred despite having autism, being homosexual or suffering some form of trauma or sexual abuse”.Speaking on Radio , she added that children as young as nine were being asked to consent “to a completely experimental treatment for which long-term consequences are not known”.But gender ersity advocates warn that “a loss to trans youth is a loss to all”.Time will tell the outcome of her case but, meanwhile, in unrelated comments, I note that the actor Rupert Everett says he spent most of his early childhood wanting “to be a girl”.He adored his mother, aunt and grandmother, didn’t like men, and adds: “I loved necklaces and bras and all those kinds of things.”Then, when he reached , he “didn’t want to be a girl any more. I really enjoyed being a homosexual”.The case in point, perhaps, for treading very carefully indeed with pre-teens.POLICE officers will be required to have degrees from this year – a move that could remove , recruits from the front line while they complete their studies.Sigh. Really When it comes to tackling crime on our streets, the majority of us want someone on our side who possesses instinct, courage and common sense.Which you either have or don’t regardless of qualications.NATURISTS John and Donna Price have moved from Kent to Lincolnshire for more privacy because they like to barbecue in the nude.“I love a flambeed banana,” says Donna, .Oooer.Aren’t our AEs under enough pressure Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ross clark huawei 5g network
story: This is a company that has brought us the technology of an iPhone but at a fraction of the cost.I am no protectionist and I don’t fear the Chinese.When it comes to selling us consumer goods, I am more than happy to welcome China’s companies into the country to compete with British, European or US-made products.But it is a very dferent matter when it comes to allowing a Chinese company to build Britain’s next- generation broadband network — with all the security issues that raises.Unbelievably, the Government is seriously considering doing just this.Yesterday, the Prime Minister — who is due to make a decision next month on whether to award Huawei a contract to build parts of Britain’s G network — indicated that he is inclined to give the company the nod.Critics, he said, needed to suggest which other company ought to be allowed to do the work.I am sorryI am a little ignorant on this point. While I have bought several mobile phones, I have never gone shopping for an entire telecoms network.But surely there must be other potential contractors. Don’t we have a telecoms industry of our own It doesn’t say much for the Government’s privatisation of BTit is not in the running for this sort of work.What about our own Vodafone, which I thought was one of the world leaders in mobile phone technology Evendepriving Huawei of the work meant we had to wait a little longer or pay a little extra to download a movie to our phones, that would surely be a reasonable price to pay for protecting national security.And national security policy really is at stake.Yesterday the US reaffirmed that allowing Huawei to build our G network — even parts of it which are deemed to be low- risk — would be “madness” and could compromise the willingness of the US to share vital intelligence with Britain in future.This didn’t come in one of Donald Trump’s notorious am tweets but from officials working for Matt Pottinger, the US deputy national security adviser, and Robert Blair, special representative for international telecommunications policy.That they took the trouble to visit London to warn of the dangers we could be getting ourselves into ought to be seen as a red flag on Huawei’s involvement in our G network.Surely, the importance of being able to share intelligence with our most important ally should rank above pure considerations of cost.Australia has already blocked the Chinese firm from its G network.Yet here, the head of MI Sir Andrew Parker said he had “no reason” to think Britain’s intelligence partnership with the US would sufferinvolvement from the Chinese firm was given the green light.But Defence Secretary Ben Wallace underlined at the weekend that the US administration has threatened to cut off some intelligenceBritain approves Huawei’s involvement in G.He said: “Those things will be taken into account when the Government collectively decides to make a decision on it.”Our own Government — as it has been doing since Theresa May’s day — insists that only parts of the G contract would be awarded to Huawei.It would not be allowed to work on security-critical areas.But that isn’t good enough. Such is the complexity of modern telecommunications networks that it would be impossible to be sure that systems installed in one part of the network were not enabling data to be obtained from another.Whoever designs and builds a telecommunications system gains the power to interfere with it, or even switch it off, should it feel inclined.Of course, with modern communications a huge amount of damage can be done from afar.Evenwe are confident our broadband network is secure now, we can’t be certain that would remain the case.A company which installs a telecommunications network will necessarily continue to be involved in maintaining and upgrading the network it had designed and installed.We have to be absolutely sure the network is not being used for some underhand purpose.Huawei denies that it is controlled by the Chinese state, and has threatened to sue commentators in France whom it alleges have made that claim.But the precise relationship between Huawei and the Chinese state is hardly the point.What is certain is that China is not a democracy and there is always going to be a security issue when it comes to involving its industrial giants in sensitive work here.We would not allow a Chinese company, say, to build fighter jets for the RAF or to construct our radar defence system.This kind of work is rightly the preserve of contractors on whom we can rely totally, even in times of international conflict.Such is the importance of telecommunications in military and civil defence that we now have to think of mobile networks in the same light.The Government has been warning for years that cyber warfare is the big coming threat.In  it published a Strategic Defence Review which defined cyber attack as a “Tier One” threat alongside terrorism.Last November, the US and Taiwanese held a joint exercise in fending off a major cyber attack on Taiwan.At the time the Taiwanese Cyber Security Agency said it was the subject of an astonishing million cyber attacks every month, half of which came from the Chinese mainland.So why, then, is our own Government even considering commissioning a Chinese company to install a telecommunications network Of course, Boris Johnson is right to make it clear he is not Donald Trump’s poodle.We don’t have to take notice of everything the Americans say, on defence, trade or anything .But when it comes to our closest ally warning us that it might not want to share intelligence with us in futurewe let a Chinese company build our G network, we very much do need to take notice.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP title: eu trade deal fishing rights
story: Eurocrats hardened their position on demanding continued access to our waters after Boris Johnson vowed not to extend the transition period beyond December .The EU said talks on fisheries will now have a “direct link” to thrashing out tarf and quota free trade on goods.Previously, the EU had stated access for its vessels would be secured “within the context of the overall economic partnership”.But Mr Johnson’s insistence the UK will quit the transition come what may at the end of this year has sparked concern in Brussels.Eurocrats believe only a “bare bones” trade deal on goods will be done by then and want to play hardball over fishing for maximum leverage.In a briefing to EU diplomats, Michel Barnier’s team said any deal on “reciprocal” access would be of “unprecedented scale and scope”.The pact would include agreements on quotas that European fishermen can land in our waters and a clause to protect their livelihoods.EU negotiators want to get it done by July  this year — the date by which the UK must say whether or not it plans to extend the transition.EU trade chief Phil Hogan has suggested fishing rights may be secured in a “trade-off” with the UK over market access for the City of London.Eurocrats argue access for EU boats cannot be separated from tarf-free terms for British fish products on EU markets.The PM has vowed to take back control of UK fishing waters when the transition period ends.Commission chief Ursula von der Leyen warned the PM he wont be able to “have his cake and eat it” in trade talks. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: russia government news putin medvedev
story: The shock move is seen as part of Putins efforts to carve out a new position of power for himself to stay at the helm after his current term as president ends in .It was announced today by the president’s right-hand man, PM Dmitry Medvedev, who said it would give Putin room to carry out the changes he wants to make to the constitution.The unexpected revelation came shortly after Putin proposed a nationwide vote on sweeping changes that he said would sht power from the presidency to parliament.It is feared the move will create a powerful new position for Putin to step into once his presidency ends.The changes would likely weaken his successor and while allowing him to hold the real power as PM -with no term limits.The announcement means Russia will also get a new prime minister.Possible candidates include Sergei Sobyanin, the mayor of Moscow, Maxim Oreshkin, the economy minister, or Alexander Novak, the energy minister.Medvedev made the announcement on state TV sitting next to Putin who thanked Medvedev, a close ally, for his work.The president said Medvedev will now take on a new job as deputy head of Russias Security Council, which Putin chairs.Medvedev, a longtime pal of Putins, has served as Russias PM since .He spent four years before that as president in -, becoming a placeholder when Putin had to switch into the PMs office because of constitutional term limits on the presidency.Medvedev then obediently stepped down after just one term as president and let Putin reclaim the top job.The move was widely seen as cynical political manoeuvring and triggered massive protests in MoscowPutin asked for the outgoing government to remain at work until a new government was appointed.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk weather forecast storm brendan
story: A stunning snap captures the moment ft waves battered the windows at Oliver’s On The Beach, in Southend-on-Sea, Essex, amid Storm Brendan.Care-free customers can even be seen laughing and eating as extreme weather today hit the seaside café.The frothing seawater can be seen smashing the window which juts onto the iconic beach beloved by British holidaymakers.It came as Storm Brendan has sparked  flood alerts as it leaves a trail of devastation across the UK - with more rain on the way tomorrow according to weather forecasters.Brits will have to brace themselves for showers after the terrible conditions caused chaos across the country’s roads.Airlines were forced to ert flights scheduled to land at Gatwick Airport on Monday evening while ferries and railways faced disruption.In Christchurch, Dorset, high tides flooded car parks by the quay, with the same happening in nearby Mudeford.Local resident Steve Hogen, who filmed the flooding in the early hours of this morning, said: Ive lived in Mudeford for  years and I personally think the flooding is getting more often and worse.Inland, the River Avon burst its bank, spilling on to roads near Chippenham, Wiltshire, and leaving some vehicles stranded.Clear-up work has continued in Slough, Berkshire, after high winds blew a roof off a residential and commercial building on to the High Street on Tuesday.Taxi driver Haris Baig, , said he had to slam on his brakes as a large section of roof crashed in front of him, said: It was a disaster. It was a miracle no-one was killed.In Orpington, London, scaffolding collapsed overnight on Monday closing a road, but no-one was injured.On Tuesday, a car was pictured in the sea during rising tides in Starr Gate near Blackpool, Lancashire, but was later recovered by the Coastguard.Meanwhile  homes are without power near Stroud, Glos, and another  near Exeter, Devon.But Brendan seems to have more up its sleeve with the environment agency issuing  flood warnings and  flood alerts from Devon to Gretna on the Scottish coast.A yellow warning of wind covering much of England expired at am, while a rain warning covering south-east England stopped at am. Meteorologist Alex Burkill, from the Met Office, said: It will take a little while but the rain should clear by lunchtime.Once it does clear away, otherwise tomorrow, most places are in for some decent sunny spells.There could be further thundery showers mainly to the north and west of the UK, with the chance of sleet and snow across the hills and mountains of Scotland and Northern Ireland, according to the forecaster.Rail passengers face delays and temporary speed limits due to the heavy winds and fallen trees, while drivers have been advised to take extra care on the roads.Although the wind is due to ease off today, conditions will still be blustery, Mr Burkill said, and temperatures are due to dip slightly to nine degrees.But he warned that more unsettled weather was ahead on Thursday, particularly during the second half of the day, when places across the country could expect wet and windy weather.It doesnt look as bad as what weve had through the past couple of days, he added.At the moment it looks like well stay warning free . Its just a windy day rather than a hazardous one.A gust of mph was recorded on the Isle of Wight on Tuesday, while the village of Libanus in Brecon Beacons National Park, Wales, saw mm of rainfall in  hours, according to the Met Office.Portuguese man o wars are often hard to spot in the water and can be as little as a foot long but their tentacles can grow up to a staggering ft and are virtually invisible.Beach-goear Kimberley Alaaeldin spotted one of the jellyfish as she visited Par Beach and Carlyon Bay, near St Austell, Cornwall, this morning.Man o war have also been spotted on Wembury beach in south Devon, and in Dorset.National Geographic magazine warned Beware - even dead man-of-wars washed up on shore can deliver a sting.The “Floating Terror” has long tentacles that can cause a painful sting and be fatal in extremely rare cases.The NHS website states: Pain from a Portuguese man o war sting usually lasts about - minutes.Get immediate medical helpyou experience severe, lasting pain, orthe affected area becomes infected.

title: meghan markle and prince harry left for canada because of how good the chocolate is diplomats joke
story: The Sussexes visited The Canadian High Commission in Trafalgar Square the day before making their bombshell announcement last week.They were treated to Nanaimo bars - a famous Canadian dessert which originates from Vancouver Island, where the Royal couple spent six weeks over Christmas.Canadian diplomats joked that the chocolate treats convinced them to make the move permanent.A source told The Sun: They loved the chocolate - at the end of the night they even askedthey could take a plate of it home with them.And speaking at a drinks reception on Monday night, the Canadian High Commissioner said: I think it was their visit to Canada House last week that sealed the deal.Nanaimo bars have been a famous Canadian icon for decades and last year featured on a Canada Post stamp.It comes as pals of the couple claimed they were forced to leave by bad blood in the royal family.

story: The Labour boss spoke out after the Duchess was seen in Canada for the first time yesterday since announcing that she and Prince Harry would be stepping down as senior royals and wanted to spend more time in North America.The royals are currently thrashing out how the pair plan to become financially independent from the rest of the family - but Meghan has already flown back to Canada to be with baby Archie.Mr Corbyns spokesperson said this lunchtime: Jeremy has commented in the past in relation to Prince Harry and Meghan about press intrusion and its impact on people and their families.To use Prince Harrys words as well - the racial undertones in relation to how the media has approached Meghan.He [Corbyn] has spoken out about the concerns and obviously understands how press intrusion can have a negative impact on people and their private lives.Prince Harry accused the press of subjecting Meghan to a “wave of abuse and harassment” in November .And some commentators have claimed the pair are fleeing their roles to escape racism.However, Mr Corbyns spokesperson failed to give any examples of racist coverage.They said: Im not going to run through the full gamut of the coverage. title: meghan harry new life in canada
story: It’s no surprise the couple have chosen the country she called home for seven years while she starred in Suits.But Britain’s deep links with the Commonwealth nation also make it a perfect stepping stone out of royal le.The first line of Canada’s constitution declares itself “under the crown of the United Kingdom of Great Britain”.But how will the Sussexes fare in the land of bitter winters and maple leaves Here, we take a closer look at how the couple’s new le could work.TORONTO-based royal historian Carolyn Harris said: “Canadians tend to take less interest in the private lives of public figures.“There isn’t the same culture of paparazzi as in Britain or the US.”Indeed, no paparazzi photos emerged of the Sussexes during their recent seven-week holiday on Vancouver Island.The local Times Colonist paper said it knew where the family was staying but didn’t ulge the details until the royals left, to “err on the side of discretion”.And on the sleepy island where Meghan and Harry spent Christmas, locals were careful to keep their distance.One, Joan Wilson, said: “Of course it piques our interest. But the last thing they want is mobs of people coming around and taking their picture.”And boat captain Miles Arsenault told how he turned down a lucrative private charter when he learned that the clients were paparazzi photographers from America and Japan, keen to get snaps of the mansion where the royals were staying.He said: “It’s hard to turn down money when you are starting a new business, but this one was an easy choice.“Canadians respect the privacy of others and I would not feel good about taking them out to take pictures of royals.”Eventhe couple moved to cosmopolitan Toronto, with a population of just under three million, it is unlikely that they would be hounded.Brit Amanda Holt, , who moved to the city  years ago, said: “I can completely understand why they would want to move here.“It is safe and private and Canadians are more politely English than English people and just don’t bother celebrities.”Nevertheless the appearance of a Sussex royal court in North America would likely attract huge media interest, not least from Meghan’s homeland, the United States.CANADA is perfectly placed to offer Archie an education with a strong nod to his British and royal heritage.A likely option would be Upper Canada College, Toronto, a private boys’ school modelled on Eton, where Harry was educated.Harry’s grandfather the Duke of Edinburgh has strong links with Upper Canada College and was on its board of governors until he retired in .Famous alumni include former newspaper baron Conrad Black and TV presenter Loyd Grossman.Boarding school Lakefield College in the province of Ontario is another option. Prince Andrew spent a year there in .If the couple settle in Vancouver, a possibility for Archie would be Pearson College on Vancouver Island.The school’s ethos is likely to appeal to Meghan and Harry’s world view.It is a United World College, one of  schools and colleges around the world in the UWC movement, which was set up to promote the principles of peace and international understanding.Built on the Pacic shore, it has an ecological reserve and marina.Douglas Alexander, the UK’s former International Development Secretary, is an ex-scholarship pupil.BEFORE she married Harry, Meghan had a well-connected social circle in Toronto, at the centre of which was stylist Jessica Mulroney.Little known in the UK, Jessica and her TV presenter husband Ben – son of former Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney – are front-page-worthy socialites in Canada, where their  wedding played out much like a royal wedding does in Britain.Jessica is from a wealthy Montreal family who founded Browns, a big Canadian footwear chain.She and Ben were childhood pals and are also friends with Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and his we Sophie.Markus Anderson is another well-connected Canadian who was befriended by Meghan.He started out as a waiter in London’s Soho House hotel and members’ club before climbing the ranks within the global chain.In , he was sent by founder Nick Jones to open Toronto’s Soho House and it was then that he met Meghan while she was starring in Suits.The pair became firms friends and, long before she met Harry, it was Markus who was introducing her to rich and powerful friends such as the Clooneys.He is believed to be a close confidant and fixer for Meghan. A source said: “He knows everyone. He’s utterly discreet.”THE current bill for the Duke and Duchess’s taxpayer-funded Met Police protection team is about £, a year. That would soarit went with them to Canada.During their seven-week stay on Vancouver Island the Sussexes were shadowed round the clock by six armed Met officers.That meant the overall team was at least ten strong, to provide continuous protection.It has not yet been decided who will pay the bill as the Sussexes split their time between the UK and Canada.Canadian finance minister Bill Morneau said there have not yet been discussions about who will cover security costs.He said: “We haven’t spent any time thinking about this issue. We obviously are always looking to make sure that as a member of the Commonwealth we play a role.”Speaking before the Queen’s statement on Monday, Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said: “Most Canadians are very supportive of having royals be here. But what kind of costs are involved, there’s still lots of discussions to be had.”The Duke and Duchess have already dropped their public claim to be “internationally protected people” in a sign that security is proving a sensitive subject in negotiations.Last Wednesday, the couple insisted they were legally entitled to armed police protection funded by the taxpayer, with their new website stating: “The Duke and Duchess of Sussex are classied as internationally protected people, which mandates this level of security.”But this was deleted after questions were raised about the level of Government-funded security they could expect.The legal concept of internationally protected people dates from a  UN convention set up to protect diplomats and political leaders.It was introduced into UK law in the  Internationally Protected Persons Act, which afforded “special protection” to heads of state, people representing them, PMs and diplomats.HARRY and Meghan are hardly on their uppers – with a reported £million joint fortune.Yet they will now need a rich revenue stream after announcing on their Sussex Royal website that they want to be “members of the Royal Family with financial independence”.Last June they trademarked the “Sussex Royal” brand in the UK for items including books, clothing, charitable fundraising, education and social care services.They are also said to be registering Sussex Royal as a global trademark covering areas including clothing, stationery and “emotional support” groups.Meghan has stealthily moved her company Frim Fram to the US state of Delaware, which is known for providing secrecy to the super-rich and low personal income tax rates.The firm ran her lestyle blog, The Tig, before she became a royal. She may now relaunch the site.The couple may also explore brand partnerships and commercial tie-ups which would have to be delicately balanced with their royal duties.The couple may also be tempted to sign book, TV and film deals.Barack and Michelle Obama signed a book deal worth £million and signed a deal with Netflix to make documentaries on social and political activism.The royal pair may also be attracted to public speaking to promote their causes. One LA agency boss says they could get as much as £, per engagement in the US.There are complicated tax implications for them on splitting le between the UK and Canada.Under Canadian law anyone who spends  days or more in the country has to pay income tax there on global earnings.If the pair spend less time abroad they will be expected to pay tax in the UK on any income earned from working in Canada.Matters are further complicated by the fact that Meghan is a US citizen. She has to pay US taxes on global earnings, no matter where she lives.Canada will not automatically grant the couple citizenship, and they would need to apply to become permanent residents through the normal immigration process.That means Harry will be entering Canada as any other British citizen would, and all British citizens can stay in Canada for up to six months without a visa, as is the case for US citizens.So Harry and Meghan’s short-term plan could simply be to travel back and forth between Canada and the UK at least twice a year – although that would risk Meghan’s application for British citizenship.Immigration experts say she may have obtained a self-employed visa when she worked on Suits.That would mean she is still eligible to live and work in Canada in any field, and that she could sponsor Harry and Archie.The couple could also qualy for a business visathey invested some of their wealth in Canada, andthey successfully monetised the Sussex brand, Canada could be eager to welcome them as taxpaying citizens.THE couple spent Christmas in a multi-million pound, , sq ft mansion on Vancouver Island on Canada’s west coast.The pad has breathtaking scenery and is popular with millionaires and retirees.According to local reports, the pair took full advantage of the outdoorsy lestyle during their break and were spotted jogging and hiking.The well-heeled island, or the nearby city of Vancouver itself, could be an ideal spot for them, given that it is just a three-hour hop by plane from Meghan’s native Los Angeles.But sources think the couple would opt for a more permanent home in Toronto, a city that Meghan knows well.The couple will doubtless find a grander property than the £,, three-bedroom home that Meghan rented while making Suits.The family couldto the laid-back, family-friendly area known as The Annex, close to the city centre.Toronto has a wealth of leafy, well-heeled neighbourhoods including Forest Hill and Deer Park, where Meghan’s close pal Jessica Mulroney lives.An even more upmarket option is the exclusive enclave of Bridle Path, also near the city centre.Dubbed “Canada’s Beverly Hills”, the area is the country’s most expensive neighbourhood, with multi-million-pound, gated hide-aways for the rich.Rapper Drake had his own bespoke mansion built on two acres of land, complete with hot tub, basketball court, pool and gym.Both Toronto and Vancouver have booming TV and film industries, which may well be a draw for Meghanshe wants toto acting or pursue a career as a director, as has been rumoured.Industry tax breaks have seen both cities double their share of film locations for big-budget US movies and TV shows.Good Will Hunting, The Incredible Hulk, The Revenant and TV’s The Handmaid’s Tale were all shot in Canada – where the changeable climate has earned it the nickname Brollywood.AS monarch, the Queen – Harry’s granny – is Canada’s head of state and appoints the Governor General, currently ex-astronaut Julie Payette, to carry out most of her royal duties there.There have been calls for Harry to be given the job – thereby giving him a constitutional role in the Commonwealth country whose citizens would then be less likely to begrudge taxpayers funding his security.A poll taken just two days before Harry and Meghan’s announcement showed  per cent of Canadians were in favour of the Prince taking up the role.The Queen and her Governor General have two official residences – Ottawa’s Rideau Hall and the Citadelle of Quebec.Prince Arthur, son to Queen Victoria, served as Governor General from  to .GOT a story title: prince harry meghan markle not welcome in canada
story: A scathing editorial in The Globe and Mail has declared that no member of the Royal family can ever make Canada their home.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex got their way at the Royal Family’s crisis summit — but the Queen made it plain she is deeply upset they are quitting.After the Sandringham talks, Her Majesty released a statement saying the couple will be allowed to step down from their duties and spend time in Canada.But she said: “Although we would have preferred them to remain full-time working members of the Royal Family, we respect and understand their wish to live a more inde­pendent le.”And following the news, the respected paper has voiced its opposition to Harry and Meghan moving to Canada.It said any move by the couple would violate laws that keep the once-British-ruled country at arm’sfrom the UK.The paper said: “You are welcome to visit, but so long as you are senior royals, Canada cannot allow you to come to stay.It breaks an unspoken constitutional taboo.Harry flew back to the UK this week for the crisis summit while Meghan waited at the couples £m Vancouver mansion during the talks.The prince is expected to fly back to his we and baby Archie next week at the plush Canadian pad where they spent their extended Christmas break - although a riddle over who actually owns it has deepened as a controversial mining tycoon denied it was his.The couple will now go through a period of transition that will see them create a new le as a young family and spend time in both Canada and the UK.The Queen said she was “entirely supportive of Harry and Meghan’s desire to create a new le as a young family”.The summit, which took almost four hours, took place between the Queen, Prince Charles, and brothers William and Harry.The fine detail of the agreement — especially the controversial issue of who will fund the couple’s new le — will be thrashed out over the next few days.But The Globe and Mail blasted: “[Canada’s] unique monarchy, and its delicate yet essential place in our constitutional system, means that a royal resident — the Prince is sixth in the line of succession — is not something that Canada can allow.“A royal living in this country does not accord with the long-standing nature of the relationship between Canada and Britain, and Canada and the Crown.“Though Canada borrowed from Britain, it isn’t Britain and never was. And this country long ago took steps to make that unmistakably clear.“If you’re a senior member of our Royal Family, this country cannot become your home.”It comes after Canada appeared to rein back a pledge to pay Harry and Meghan’s £ million-a-year security bill should they move there.Prime Minister Justin Trudeau is understood to have privately assured The Queen his government would partially fund protection for the couple and son Archie.But Finance Minister Bill Morneau has warned federal officials have yet to make a decision on the crucial contribution amid fears the nation’s taxpayers would object.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: big ben must chime for brexit the miserabilists and pessimists cannot get their way
story: As Britain throws off the shackles of rule by the European Union, a new era of national freedom beckons.The arrival of British independence, after nearly half a century of Brussels domination, is a moment for profound celebration.And there could be no more appropriate way to mark this historic milestone than a series of chimes from the mighty bell that is Big Ben.For the landmark is a shining symbol of both British nationhood and our parliamentary democracy.Since its completion in , the clock tower synonymous with its famous bell has become a cultural icon, renowned across the world.At a height of ft, its majestic beauty epitomises the greatness of our country. The distinctive peal from its massive, .-ton bell is a part of the soundtrack of our public le.But sadly, it now seems likely that the advent of Brexit will be met by silence from Big Ben.If the parliamentary authorities have their way, no sound will echo from the clock tower on that momentous night.Since , the building has been undergoing a major renovation programme, including the installation of a lt, resurfacing of the dials, and restoration of the clock mechanism.According to the House of Commons Commission, which oversees the Westminster estate, the cost of interrupting this work to enable Big Ben to chime for Brexit would be more than £,.We are told this huge bill arises because of the need to install a temporary floor in the belfry to support the chiming equipment — as well as the impact of delays, for up to four weeks, in the renovation project.In the view of pessimistic officialdom, the whole idea of the Brexit chimes is just too expensive.As Sir Lindsay Hoyle, the new Speaker of the Commons, put it this week, “You are talking about £, a bong.”The arch-Remainers have, predictably, seized on the problem with glee.For them, the entire business is just like Brexit itself — a pointless, costly distraction.That negativity is shared by large parts of the civil service and Westminster establishment.Viewing Brexit with horror, they seek to prevent any inspirational commemoration of the event.So the supposed heavy costs give them the perfect excuse to do nothing, just as they used bureaucratic stalemate to thwart Brexit for years.Indeed, the Big Ben dficulty can be seen as ato Project Fear, once more, where dire financial warnings are deployed to frighten the public into inaction.But the British people did not give in to Project Fear , and they should not be cowered by more alarmism this time.The shrill negative voice of Remainers had dominated for too long.After the decisive General Election last month, that is the noise that should be hushed, not the chimes of Big Ben.Expressions of national pride are a force for benevolence and unity, as we witnessed in the recent cricket World Cup triumph.Despite all the Remainer gloom, there is a tremendous yearning to celebrate British-ness.That spirit can also be seen in the broad popular support for the idea of a new Festival of Britain, in , to extol the values of our nation.Once again, just as with their negativity over Big Ben, the pro-EU brigade sneered at the concept as nothing more than a Festival of Brexit, which could only enshrine entrenched isions.But in reality, just like the successful post-war Festival of Britain in , the  Festival could achieve the very opposite, by enabling us to reconnect with our identity, heritage and future.The same can be true of the Brexit chimes on January . It can be an occasion for joy and openness, not misery and fearfulness.Boris Johnson’s suggestion that the £, bill could be met by an appeal to the public is being scuppered by senior officials.In his usual inimitable style, Boris had asked for crowd-funding citizens to “bung a bob for a Big Ben bong”. There were signs the campaign could be taking off.The passionate Euro-sceptic MP Mark Francois pledged £,, while there was also speculation that millionaires such as Lord Ashcroft and Wetherspoon pub chain boss Tim Martin could make large donations.Officials yesterday said there was “no legal basis” for using public donations. So why shouldn’t the Government chip in  After all, the state is used to bankrolling exceptional national events, often at a far bigger cost.A reported £million went on Meghan and Harry’s wedding in .Most of that was swallowed up by security, but £, alone went on her bridal dress — which is not far off the cost of the Big Ben bongs.Similarly, the bill for the chimes is barely a quarter of the more than £million estimated to be spent on the official London fireworks display on New Year’s Eve.But before any money is handed over by the public or Treasury, the huge potential bill — £, to get the bell to chime, plus the £, cost of delays to the tower’s repair — must be challenged.In all kinds of major projects, because of weak management, contractors and consultants often expand the budgets for their own interests.We have seen that process with the HS rail link, now on course to cost over £billion, while even with the renovation of Big Ben the project’s bill has risen from an original £million to £million.On Tuesday night, one former project manager in Parliament said the estimate for the chimes had been absurdly inflated.“I cannot believe the costs you’re talking about,” he told LBC radio.The can-do, anti-establishment outlook ensured the victory of Brexit. With the same imagination and drive, the campaign for the Big Ben chimes can succeed.In fact, it could be the cue for a string of other celeb-rations across our land on January , like bonfires, fire-work displays or big screen-ings in city squares.But at the centre of it all has to be the Westminster clock tower. As Nigel Farage put it, “If Big Ben doesn’t sound, our country looks like a joke.”The miserabilists and pessimists must not get their way.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. The Prime Minister called yesterday for a crowdfunding campaign to ring the Great Bell in Parliament at pm on January . And with a £, cost of reattaching the bellaposs clapper , itaposs no surprise itaposs made headlines. However, as you might have guessed, Boris Johnson is still the Prime Minister and his government - not to mention bodies like the police and NHS - are still doing things that affect your le. We in the media have been covering those too - though naturally, sometimes, talk of a big bell ringing turns more heads.  So as a public service, here are seven genuinely important things, policies or stories that have emerged since the bell talk began yesterday morning that you might have missed. Who knows, perhaps some of these issues could even use £, of help. . A report revealed how a child grooming gang roamed the streets in plain sight  A child grooming gang was left to roam the streets in aposplain sightapos and abuse and rape dozens of victims, a report found yesterday. The appalling scale of the abuse in Manchester was laid bare  years later in the aposassurance reportapos, which looked at how girls were hooked on drugs, groomed, raped and emotionally broken by up to  members of the gang. One girl, Victoria Agoglia, who was aged just , was forcibly injected with heroin and died two months later. Abusers were allowed to freely pick up and have sex with children from city centre care homes, in plain sight of officials, the report found. Many girls also explicitly reported that they were being made to take part in apossex partiesapos with groups of men who plied them with alcohol and drugs. The report looked at how Greater Manchester Policehandled the horric street grooming and abuse of at least  vulnerable girls across the city. The four-hour AE waiting time target could be scrapped after the NHS recorded its worst figure on record, a top Tory hinted today. Health Secretary Matt Hancock revived the long-standing threat to rip up the promise following the election - and  years after it was set by Labour . Since  hospitals have been told to see % of AE patients within four hours. But the target has not been met since  and Tory ministers have repeatedly threatened to scrap it. Twelve months ago, both Theresa May and the head of the NHS suggested the could be scrapped. And today, Mr Hancock told BBC Radio  Live: We will be judged by the right targets. Targets have to be clinically appropriate. Furious Shadow Health Secretary Jon Ashworth said: Changing the AE target won’t magic away the problems in our overcrowded hospitals, with patients left on trolleys in corridors for hours and hours. Any review of targets must be transparent and based on watertight clinical evidence. Otherwise patients will think Matt Hancock is trying to move the goalposts to avoid scrutiny of the governmentaposs record. . Hundreds of thousands are living without a fridge Hundreds of thousands of people in the UK are living without a fridge, a benefits charity said today. Turnus revealed the shocking figure to highlight what it described as millions living in poverty without basic white goods. The charity commissioned a survey of , people earning less than £, in December  by private research firm Dynata. Of those who responded,  - .% - said they were living without at least one of a cooker, fridge, freezer or washing machine. In all .% said they were living without a cooker, .% without a fridge, .% without a freezer and .% without a washing machine. The charity used the data to produce a rough estimate today that , people are living without a fridge in the UK. The charity claimed Tory welfare reforms since  had contributed signicantly to the increase in appliance poverty. A spokesman said  of  charities had pointed to the decision to scrap a system of crisis loans called the Social Fund in . The Department for Work and Pensionssaid people on Universal Credit can get a budgeting advance to help with similar costs.  Home Secretary Priti Patel issued a written statement yesterday tightening up the rules on less lethal weapons. From now on, new weapons systems will be banned from being used by the police until they have been explicitly approved by the Home Secretary. The move was recommended in a damning report that was issued after a public inquiry into the death of Anthony Grainger. Father-of-two Mr Grainger was behind the wheel of a stolen Audi in Culcheth, Cheshire, when a Greater Manchester Police officer, referred to in court as Q, fired his Heckler  Koch MP submachine gun. During  weeks of evidence in , Q told Liverpool Crown Court from behind a screen that he believed Mr Grainger, , had reached down asto grab a firearm. But the inquiry heard that no firearms were found on Mr Grainger or in the stationary vehicle in a public car park off Jackson Avenue in the early evening of March , . . The UK escalated a major dispute over Iranaposs nuclear deal  The ongoing diplomatic row with Iran took a new turn yesterday when France, Britain and Germany formally triggered the dispute mechanism in Iranaposs nuclear deal. It was the first time the three nations chose to enforce an agreement that requires Iran to curb its nuclear programme. Triggering the mechanism amounts to formally accusing Iran of violating the terms of the deal. It could lead eventually to reimposing UN sanctions that were lted under the  pact. Boris Johnson yesterday said he would back Donald Trump in ripping up the nuclear pact -thereaposs a Trump deal for Iran instead.  Yesterday, therevealed the UK has been accused of failing to pass on the details of , convictions of foreign criminals to their home EU countries and covering up the scandal. An error with the police national computer meant that EU countries were not told about the crimes committed, the sentences given doled out by UK courts or the risk they posed to the public. The police national computer error went undetected for five years. According to theduring that time one in three alerts on criminals were not sent to EU member states. Dangerous criminals could have travelled back to their home countries without the normal notication to local authorities of their presence. Christine Jardine MP, Liberal Democrat Home Affairs spokesperson, said: “UK police rely on EU-wide data-sharing systems to identy criminals and keep us safe. For the Home Office to fail so badly to live up to its side of that agreement is shameful.“The Home Office has serious questions to answer over this. Not just the failure to pass on details of convicted criminals to other EU countries, but the cover up afterwards as well.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA -year-old new Labour MP has called for an end to  years of Thatcherism in a damning first speech in Parliament. Zarah Sultana broke with the tradition of being light-hearted in her maiden speech to slam not just the Toriesapos record - but events on Tony Blairaposs watch too. In an address to fellow MPs she said: Ten years ago I was sitting my GCSEs at school. I was a teenager and I never dreamed I would be here today. In ten years’ time, at the start of the the next decade, I want to look teenagers in the eye and say with pride - my generation faced  years of Thatcherism and we ended it. We faced rising racism and we defeated it. We faced a planet in peril - we saved it. We have our work cut out but together we can do it. Ex-PM Margaret Thatcher, who took power  years ago and changed the political landscape of the UK away from the state and towards the private sector, once claimed Tony Blair and New Labour were her greatest achievement. But defenders of Labouraposs time in office from  to  point out the party introduced the minimum wage, Sure Start centres, devolution, school and hospital funding and many more.  During the election Ms Sultana apologised for a tweet five years ago that said she would celebrate the deaths of Mr Blair, Israelaposs Benjamin Netanyahu and former US President George Bush. The  Twitter post in her name published by the Jewish Chronicle said: aposDonapost celebrate the death of any person regardless of what they did.apos Try  stop me when the likes of Blair, Netanyahu and Bush die. Another post said: Those within the student movement who go to Zionist conferences and trips should be ashamed of themselves. You’re advocating racist ideology. She said the posts dating to her student days were written out of frustration rather than any malice. Ms Sultana held Coventry South for Labour in last monthaposs election, but with a majority slashed from , to . Ms Sultana also used todayaposs speech to call for MPs to set up Parliament in Coventry when they are forced to leave the Palace of Westminster for renovation work. The MP, whose family moved to the UK from Kashmir, today said her generation had been betrayed by almost a decade of Tory austerity.She told the House of Commons: I know convention is for maiden speeches to avoid saying anything members opposite will find disagreeable. But I can’t do that. Because my generation has only ever faced a future of rising rents, frozen wages and diminishing opportunities. For my whole adult le I’ve only known Tory governments that wage war on working-class communities like mine.

title: manchester grooming gangs would been
story: NewsopinionThe Manchester grooming gangs would have been stamped outtheir victims were someone other than poor young girlsRace and religion has been blamed for systematic child abuse, but the creation of an underclass of the "undeserving poor" means they are still getting away with itShareByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsopinion" to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailIf  pensioners from Tunbridge Wells had been raped in plain sight of their carers, heads would roll. If  grammar school boys,  besuited City workers,  MPs or  police officers were stalked for years by a gang of sex abusers, it would cause legal and social upheaval.  But  poor girls from south Manchester  Girls who were poor, born to parents who could not look after them, in care, with no hope, no way out, and no prospects, girls who seem pre-destined for a le of abuse, crime, and addiction  Well, letaposs not be too hasty, lads. We donapost want to make Rusholme look bad. We donapost want to put too much pressure on the police. We have enough problems with race. These girls arenapost angels. And there might be political concerns. Letaposs just agree itaposs all very sad and shut down the investigation because we know all about it, now.The report into the Manchester grooming scandal which was published yesterday quotes one detective who helped arrest and charge a rapist who was not Asian. He said: It was a prosperous middle-class area, and they were well-to-do kids. They werenapost from the original tranche of children that were in childrenaposs homes... we were told to try and get other ethnicities.If you raped a rich kid, you got nicked. And coppers werenapost told to catch rapists. They were told to tick boxes. In Rusholme, Rotherham, Peterborough, Oxford, Rochdale, Bristol, Telford, Newcastle, Aylesbury, Huddersfield, and Keighley, the children who should be most protected by the state were hung out to dry by servants of that state. The authorities ignored, covered up, and swept under the carpet hundreds,not thousands, of horrying crimes.Many tried, and failed, to get their managers to act when girls were injected with drugs, groomed, raped, beaten, made pregnant, given abortions, and had their children taken away. But all too often, the authorities were wilfully-blind partners in the abuse. This is what happens, when you politicise the police with locally-elected crime commissioners. When chief constables get too pally with council leaders. When social workers are blamed for not doing the things politicians stop them doing. Well-funded childrenaposs services look after children. Police officers who donapost care for politics chase criminals of all races. And an NHS with the time and staff to track, counsel and help the most dficult people it has to deal with can link up with other services to see the full picture, not just the black eye. Butyouaposre one of the unlucky ones, youaposre on your own. Five years ago, Professor Alexis Jayaposs report into child sex abuse in Rotherham found that white and Asian girls were victims of men who were of Pakistani, Kosovan and Kurdish heritage. They were mostly Muslim, but included other races and faiths too. White victims were more likely to come forward, but were not treated fairly because of officials contemptuous about race, class and gender.The rapists told their victims - which included Sikh, Hindu and Muslim girls - they were targeted because they were the wrong sort of girl. And everyone seems to have taken the rapists at their word. The bigger truth is they were targeted because they didnapost matter. Black or white, they were poor. They were girls. And they didnapost matter to their rapists, the police, or the politicians.  When Victoria Agoglia died of an overdose aged , the coroner recorded a narrative verdict saying she was known to grant sexual favours to men infor drugs.Two months before her death, Victoria had reported that she was being raped and injected with heroin by an older man. No effort - none - was made to help her. And even so, a coroner said her rape was a favour she had granted. Every rapist picks someone they can control. Someone who wonapost be believed. And what better victim than a kid in care, with track marks on her arms. Britain has created a new underclass. People who, more than a century ago, were called the undeserving poor, people who made their own problems and did not observe the rules of dress, work and manners that the God-fearing, hard-working poor did.  The Victorians changed their minds about the poor, eventually. Journalists exposed the scandal of children sold into prostitution, laws were changed, slums were cleared, living standards improved. When the boom of the s was replaced by the Great Depression and everyone feared the breadline, moves began for the welfare state that was introduced only after two world wars had destroyed our class barriers.A century on, weaposve built those barriers again.There are places only some sorts of people live, eat, and work. They get less money spent on them. The streets are not swept as often. The landlords go unchecked. The schools are expected to be bad.It is those places who bred the rapists, and their victims. They created ignorance, otherness, and a world with dferent rules. Racism of all sorts festered, to the point that men of all faiths believed poor girls were easy meat, and the rest believed it was just what men like them did.The same places have bred county lines drug dealers, kne gangs, and other socially-expensive forms of misery. This underclass consists of hundreds of thousands of people, victims and criminals, and untold thousands of children who are still being raped.  Lessons were learned after the Rotherham scandal was first exposed in . They were learned again when a gang was jailed in , in  in Rochdale and the House of Commons, in  after the Jay report and again in  and , after  men and  women were convicted. But their crimes dated back to the s. The council knew of them in the s. Predominantly-male local officials, whose own families were unlikely to be victims, ignored it all and decided it was more important they got re-elected.The lessons learned are usually that victims must have their crimes prosecuted. Itaposs all but useless for most vulnerable children, who distrust the authorities, who are kept apart, addicted, or who see no way out. A prosecution makes bugger all dference to the basic problem which is that we now asks ourselves who deserves justice, and who does not.  To the short-sighted, Islam is to blame, or takeaway owners, or those of Pakistani origin. To others, itaposs the state, the namby-pamby social workers, or Labour councillors who didnapost want to upset their voting base.Very few think this is down to all of us. Since the s when this pattern of abuse began, we have ided our nation into people who deserve to do well, and those who donapost. People who work hard, and those on benefits. Those we want to live next door to, and those we donapost.We have not noticed it, but all the evidence shows we have also ided ourselves into people who deserve to be victims, and those who deserve a police investigation. Those who deserve hope, and those doomed to hopelessness. This wound on our soft underbelly will kill us, unless it is disinfected. The people most in need of help, of good schools, of education, and the full attention of all the authorities, must get it - and at the expense of those who can manage without it. The lessons have not been learned. Tough sentences will not stop further offences. Someone like Victoria is being raped, today, not because of race or religion but because more than one person has decided that child deserves to be raped. The only way to stop it is to admit that weaposd all be in that underclass, with a little bad luck. And tell our leaders that no-one deserves to be stuck in it.
